title: Isla de Mona e Islote Monito, Mayagüez, Puerto Rico
text:
Isla de Mona e Islote Monito is an island-barrio of <a href="Mayag%C3%BCez%2C%20Puerto%20Rico">Mayagüez, Puerto Rico</a>. The US <a href="census">census</a> of 2000 reports six housing units, but a population of zero. The barrio is made up of the islands of <a href="Mona%2C%20Puerto%20Rico">Mona</a> and <a href="Monito%20Island">Monito</a>. In 2010, there was a population of 5. This is the largest ward of Mayagüez by area. The total land area of both islands in the barrio is about 56.93 km2 (Mona Island 56.783 km2 and nearby <a href="Monito%20Island">Monito Island</a> 0.147 km2), and it comprises 28.3 percent of the total land area of the municipality of Mayagüez. <a href="Desecheo%20Island">Desecheo Island</a>, 49 km to the northeast, is part of Sabanetas barrio. The <a href="Mona%20Island%20Lighthouse">Mona Island Lighthouse</a> is located in the ward. Isla de Mona e Islote Monito is surrounded by the <a href="Mona%20Passage">Mona Passage</a>.
History.
Puerto Rico was ceded by <a href="Spain">Spain</a> in the aftermath of the <a href="Spanish%E2%80%93American%20War">Spanish–American War</a> under the terms of the <a href="Treaty%20of%20Paris%20of%201898">Treaty of Paris of 1898</a> and became an <a href="Insular%20area">unincorporated territory of the United States</a>. In 1899, the <a href="United%20States%20Department%20of%20War">United States Department of War</a> conducted a <a href="census">census</a> of Puerto Rico finding that the population of Mona was 6.
